title: Folio Works

McJannet, Voice of Elizabethan Stage Directions, 57. McJannet describes here early texts printed in roman, but those printed in black letter tend to use roman and occasionally italic as contrasting typefaces, a point she makes in “Elizabethan Speech Prefixes: Page Design, Typography, and Mimesis

which for the most part uses black letter for dialogue, roman for speech headings, and italic for stage directions and Latin. 53. A number of medieval English dramatic manuscripts position speech headings in the right margin with horizontal rules that connect them to the speeches, including the earliest Interludium de Clerico et Puella as well as The Castle of Perseverance and the Northampton Abraham and Isaac, among others. See Howard-​Hill, “Evolution of the Form of Plays
